title-group.article-title: ARIA 2016 Executive Summary: Integrated care pathways for predictive medicine across the life cycle
title-group.alt-title: Integrated care pathways for predictive medicine across the life cycle (ARIA)

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: The Allergic Rhinitis and its Impact on Asthma (ARIA) initiative commenced during a World Health Organization (WHO) workshop in 1999. The initial goals were (i) to propose a new allergic rhinitis classification, (ii) to promote the concept of multi-morbidity in asthma and rhinitis and (iii) to develop guidelines with all stakeholders for global use in all countries and populations. ARIA - disseminated and implemented in over 70 countries globally - is now focusing on the implementation of emerging technologies for individualised and predictive medicine. MASK (MACVIA (Contre les MAladies Chroniques pour un VIeillissement Actif)-ARIA Sentinel NetworK) uses mobile technology to develop care pathways in order to enable the management of rhinitis and asthma by a multi-disciplinary group or by patients themselves. An App (Android and iOS) is available in 20 countries and 15 languages. It uses a visual analogue scale to assess symptom control and work productivity as well as a clinical decision support system. It is associated with an inter-operable tablet for physicians and other health care professionals. The scaling up strategy uses the recommendations of the European Innovation Partnership on Active and Healthy Ageing (EIP on AHA). The aim of the novel ARIA approach is to provide an active and healthy life to rhinitis sufferers, whatever their age, sex or socio-economic status, in order to reduce health and social inequalities incurred by the disease.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Patients, physicians and other care providers have different options of treating allergic rhinitis (AR). Therefore, clinical practice is diverse, and patients are often not satisfied with treatment. (angl. Allergic Rhinitis and its Impact on Asthma (ARIA) initiative was established in 1999 at a WHO workshop (published in 2001). Its purpose was to establish guidelines for diagnosing and treating co-current allergic rhinitis and asthma (1,2). The ARIA initiative was updated in 2008 (1,3). The revision of 2010 drew up the first guidelines for chronic pulmonary obstruction disease that uses advanced methodology to assess evidence, grade recommendations, assess, develop and evaluate (Grading of Recommendation, Assessment, Development and Evaluation, GRADE) (4,5).

The ARIA initiative, which has been disseminated and implemented in 70 countries, is now focusing on the implementation of new technologies for personalised and predictive medicine. MASK network uses mobile technology to develop care pathways that would enable multidisciplinary groups or patients to manage rhinitis and asthma (7,8).

The goals of the new approach within the ARIA initiative is to ensure an active and healthy life to patients with rhinitis, whatever their age, gender and socio-economic status in order to reduce health and social inequalities incurred by the disease.
The article was published in December 2016 in Clinical and Translational Allergy journal.

By translating the article into Slovene, we would like present novel management of patients with a chronic disease by using modern technology that enables cooperation of all stakeholders, i.e. from pharmacists in pharmacies to general physicians and specialists.

sec.sec-type: Integrated care pathways for airway diseases, AIRWAYS ICPs): priority tasks of ARIA 2016
sec.title: Integrated care pathways for airway diseases, AIRWAYS ICPs): priority tasks of ARIA 2016
sec.p: In 2012, the European Commission launched the European Innovation Partnership on Active and Healthy Ageing (EIP on AHA). The aim was to enhance EU competitiveness and tackle societal challenges through research and innovation (9). The B3 Action Plan is devoted to the scaling up and replication of successful innovative integrated care models for chronic diseases among adult patients. Chronic respiratory diseases were selected to be the pilot project.

AIRWAYS ICPs is the implementation tool of the EPI on AHA project. AIRWAYS ICPs aims to develop practical multi-sectoral care pathways (i.e. ICPs) – of rhinitis, asthma and associated diseases by implementing new predictive medicine technology across the life cycle of patients (7,8,10). The aims are to reduce chronic respiratory disease burden, mortality and multi-morbidity, while maintaining patients’ quality-of-life (7,11). AIRWAYS ICPs has been implemented and disseminated globally (12), while becoming a sample project of the World Health Organisation Global Alliance against Chronic Respiratory Diseases (WHO GARD) (Figure 1). ARIA 2016 is a major part of AIRWAYS ICPs (13).

fig.label: Figure 1:

caption.p: Links between AIRWAYS ICPs, the European Union and WHO (adapted from Bousquet et al) (11).

fig.p: NGO: nongovernmental organisation; GO: Governmental organisation; MOH: Ministry of Health; WHO GARD World Health Organisation Global Alliance against Chronic Respiratory Diseases; NCD: Non-communicable disease; DG: Directorate General; DG Sante: Directorate-General for Health and Food Safety; DG CONNECT: The Directorate General for Communications Networks, Content and Technology; DG Research: Directorate General for Research and Innovation; AIRWAYS ICPs: Integrated care pathways for airway disease; EIP on AHA: European Innovation Partnership on Active and Healthy Ageing.

sec.sec-type: From guidelines to integrated clinical pathways: MASK network
sec.title: From guidelines to integrated clinical pathways: MASK network

sec.sec-type: The need for multi-sectoral clinical pathways for rhinitis and asthma by using ICP
sec.title: The need for multi-sectoral clinical pathways for rhinitis and asthma by using ICP
sec.p: Patients with AR are often self-managed. They rarely consult physicians on using AR drugs (14), although AR negatively impacts many activities – their social life, school and work productivity (3). Many patients with AR use over the counter drugs that are available without a prescription (15-17), only few of them consult their physician. Most patients who visit their personal physician or a specialist have moderate to severe rhinitis (18-20). Patients have several types of medication available (on prescription or OTC), can undergo specific immunotherapy or choose alternative medicine (21). According to AIRWAYS ICP recommendations, integrated clinical pathways should consider a multi-disciplinary approach, including self-management (Figure 2).

caption.p: Multi-sectoral pathway for allergic phinitis (adapted from Bosquet et al) (25).

sec.p: ICPs are structured multidisciplinary plans of care that define key steps in patient care. They promote the translation of guidelines into local protocols their application to clinical practice. ICPs differ from clinical guidelines, as they are applied by multidisciplinary teams, focusing on the quality and coordination of care. ICPs need to have a mechanism for recording variations/deviations from planned care

Variations of or deviations from recommended treatment have been carefully studied in accordance with ARIA guidelines. The severity of the disease is related to different factors of treatment and also with the quality of life (18-20). According to some studies (22) classification of rhinitis (intermittent, persistent: mild or moderate, severe) is a significant indicator of associated asthma, and the same applies to the duration and efficacy in AR treatment (23). Most patients with AR receive combinations of oral antihistamines and intra-nasal corticosteroids, which, however, are not evaluated in guidelines using an appropriate methodology (24).

sec.sec-type: Simple approach to assessing control in allergic rhinitis
sec.title: Simple approach to assessing control in allergic rhinitis
sec.p: According to ARIA guidelines, disease control rather than symptom severity is used to guide treatment decisions. The tools include:

list-item.p: visual analogue scale (VAS) as the common validated language of AR control,
categorisation of AR control using VAS score cut-offs,
incorporation of visual analogue scale into simple interactive apps for both patients (ARIA Allergy Diary) and health care providers (ARIA Allergy Diary Companion) (8,25,26),
integration of this knowledge into ICPs (25) and
the development of systems that assist in clinical decisions (clinical decision support system, CDSS).

sec.p: AR systems change daily and require increasing or decreasing individual therapeutic doses. Patients, caretakers or healthcare providers should employ a joint and simple system to score AR symptoms that can respond quickly to change. MACVIA-ARIA has produced a simple VAS-based ARIA CDSS algorithm using a VAS score to guide treatment decisions in a step-up/step-down approach (27). Using ARIA Allergy Diary Companion, a general physician or specialist can access data from the patient’s ARIA Allergy Diary and adjust therapeutic consultation with the help of ARIA CDSS algorithm.

tr.th: Q4: How do the symptoms affect me? (select):

td.p: •restrict my participation in school or work

tr.th: Q6: Are you currently receiving immunotherapy (a small dose of the thing you are allergic to, taken as an injection or placed under your tongue)?? YES/NO

tr.td: If you responded YES to Q6, please answer questions Q7 and Q8.

tr.th: Q8: How do you receive treatment?

sec.sec-type: The MASK tools: the ARIA Allergy Diary and ARIA Allergy Diary Companion apps
sec.title: The MASK tools: the ARIA Allergy Diary and ARIA Allergy Diary Companion apps
sec.p: The ARIA Allergy Diary and ARIA Allergy Diary Companion (26) are freely available to patients and health care providers in 15 EU member states, Australia, Brazil, Canada, Mexico and Switzerland. While they are available in 15 languages (translated from English into target languages, culturally adapted and legally compliant), they have not been translated into Slovene yet.

sec.title: Questionnaires
sec.p: ARIA Allergy Diary users fill in simple questionnaires on asthma, rhinitis and the impact of the disease (globally, on work and school, on daily activities and on sleep) upon registration (Table 1). The pilot study of around 5000 users (9% over 60 years of age) indicates that these questions are easily answered and can help to stratify patients with rhinitis (28). Moreover, two specific questionnaires are applied every week to assess disease impact on patients’ quality of life (29) and productivity at work (30).

sec.title: Treatment
sec.p: ARIA Allergy Diary includes a list of all treatments available for asthma, conjunctivitis and rhinitis. Users select the treatment they are taking: multiple treatments may be selected, and users can update the information if their treatment changes (Figure 3). The list has been customised for all 20 countries in which the ARIA Allergy Diary is available. On the day of first use, the patient also enters information on any allergen specific immunotherapy.

sec.title: Daily visual analogue scales
sec.p: Geolocalised users assess their daily symptom control using the touchscreen functionality on their smart phone to click on 5 consecutive visual analogue scales (global symptoms due to allergic diseases, rhinitis, conjunctivitis, asthma and work productivity) (Figure 4).

caption.p: A screen on visual analogue scales.

sec.title: Clinical decision support system
sec.p: The MASK CDSS is incorporated into an app for health care providers. It is an algorithm that aids clinicians to select pharmacotherapy for patients with AR and to stratify their disease severity (27). It uses a simple step-up/step-down individualized approach to AR pharmacotherapy.

sec.sec-type: New concepts in allergic multimorbidity included in the ARIA
sec.title: New concepts in allergic multimorbidity included in the ARIA

sec.sec-type: Stratification of patients with severe allergies and/or asthma
sec.title: Stratification of patients with severe allergies and/or asthma
sec.p: Despite the major advances in understanding allergic diseases or asthma, treatments are not effective in all patients (31). MASK tool should be used to provide more effective therapeutic interventions tailored to the individual.

Long-term birth cohort studies are essential for understanding the life course of allergic diseases (including asthma and rhinitis) and the complex interplay between genes and environment (32). Birth cohorts are longterm studies of children born in a geographical area who are then followed growing up. Some cohorts have followed up through adulthood. In the last 30 years, there have been over 100 studies of birth cohorts focusing on asthma and allergies. Merging data from several birth cohort studies also enables greater statistical capability in defining the factors influencing the course of allergies (32). The BAMSE (Barn Allergi Milj Stockholm Epidemiologi Projektet) (33) and MeDALL (Mechanisms of Development of ALLergy, European Union Framework Programme 7, project no. 261357; 2010–2015) (34) projects defined a rare phenotype which shows a proclivity towards more severe forms of allergy disease: multimorbid polysensitized phenotype, which has been confirmed in cohorts of patients with children and adults (35-38). These studies and both projects show that subjects who are polysensitised and multimorbid have a very high frequency of allergic symptoms, persistent symptoms over time, more severe asthma symptoms and higher total and specific IgE level than other phenotypes.

The results confirm that asthmatic patients cannot be managed appropriately without considering associated rhinitis. The results reinforce the importance of nasal problems (rhinitis and/or rhinosinusitis) in many uncontrolled asthmatic patients (39,40).

sec.title: Allergic multimorbidity in the elderly
sec.p: Insufficient attention has been put on the expected epidemic wave of asthma and rhinitis in older adults, who have specific symptoms and treatment needs. These patients also suffer from multi-morbidity and receive multiple medications. Integrated clinical pathways for rhinitis and asthma should cover the entire life cycle.

sec.sec-type: Growth strategy and scaling upAIRWAYs ICP in Slovenia
sec.title: Growth strategy and scaling upAIRWAYs ICP in Slovenia
sec.p: Growth strategies and scaling-up are of vital improtance, as they enable: 1. avoiding fragmentation, 2. improving health care delivery across Europe, 3. speeding up the implementation of good practices using existing cost-effective success stories and 4. meeting the EIP on AHA objectives (9). AIRWAYs ICP growth and scaling-up strategy has already been applied to the chronic respiratory diseases action plan of the EIP on AHA (12).

In Slovenia, we are planning to translation the ARIA Allergy Diary for patients and the ARIA Allergy Diary Companion for health care providers as they are not available yet. Moreover, we would like to localise the ARIA guidelines and combine them with the guidelines for rating non-allergic rhinitis. We have formed a working group that includes primary care physicians, allergology and pulmology specialists, ENT specialists, paediatricians and phamacists who are consulted in self-managed rhinitis, considering tried treatment methods.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The ARIA initiative has developed from clearly defined guidelines to a so-called implementation strategy based on mobile technology. It aims to ensure an active and healthy life to patients with rhinitis whatever their age, gender and socio-economic status in order to reduce health and social inequalities incurred by the disease.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The article was made within the project financed by the European Innovation Partnership in Active and Healthy Ageing.
